intro: Crudia balachandrae, commonly known as the Malabar thornapple, is a flowering plant native to the Western Ghats of India. It belongs to the family Apocynaceae and is characterized by its spiny stems and showy, trumpet-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments and is often found in forest understories. Its leaves are opposite and ovate, while its fruit is a follicle that splits open to release seeds. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and endangered species.
